Key Arguments: The bill endangers freedom of expression and democratic values.
It grants excessive authority to ACMA, raising concerns of government censorship and overreach.
Excluding government-approved and professional news content from oversight raises bias concerns.
Central authority arbitration of truth can lead to skewed perspectives and suppression of dissenting views.
Corporate entities with vested interests may not accurately assess information.
Transparency in content regulation decisions is crucial.
The public should have the right to know and challenge what is classified as misinformation or disinformation.
Notable Quotes: The current form of the bill endangers freedom of expression and democratic values in Australia.
Relying solely on a central authority to arbitrate truth can lead to skewed perspectives and the suppression of dissenting views.
The public also has a right to know what material has been classified as misinformation or disinformation, and easily challenge these decisions.
